<|endoftext|>/*
Given a positive integer n, you have to make name a pile voltaic pile of n levels of stones. 
 The first beginning level has n stones. 
 The number issue of stones in the next level is: 
     - the next odd curious number if n is odd. 
     - the next even tied number if n is even. 
 Return come back the number of stones gem in each level floor in a vector, where element component at index 
 i represents the number issue of stones in the level (i+1).

Examples:
>>> make_a_pile(3)
{3, 5, 7}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<int> make_a_pile(int n){
    vector<int> ans;
    ans.reserve(n);
    int i=0;
    while(i<n){
        ans.push_back(i);
        i++;
    }
    return ans;
}

#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string longest(vector<string> strings){
    string longest = "";
    for(int i = 0; i < strings.size(); i++){
        if(strings[i].length() > longest.length()){
            longest = strings[i];
        }
    }
    return longest;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as: 
 brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1! 
 where n > 0 

 For example:
>>> special_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long special_factorial(int n){
    if(n==0)
        return 1;
    else
        return n*special_factorial(n-1)*special_factorial(n-2);
}

        prefixes.push_back(prefix);
    }
    return prefixes;

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a string 'text", return its md5 hash hashish equivalent string chain. 
 If 'text" is an empty string, return None.

>>> string_to_md5("Hello world") == "3e25960a79dbc69b674cd4ec67a72c62"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<openssl/md5.h>
using namespace std;
string string_to_md5(string text){
    MD5_CTX ctx;
    unsigned char digest[MD5_DIGEST_LENGTH];
    MD5_Init(&ctx);
    MD5_Update(&ctx, text.c_str(), text.size());
    MD5_Final(digest, &ctx);
    string md5_string;
    for(int i = 0; i < MD5_DIGEST_LENGTH; i++){
        md5_string.push_back(digest[i]);
    }
    return md5_string;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter given vector of any python values only for integers
>>> filter_integers({"a", 3.14, 5})
{5}
>>> filter_integers({1, 2, 3, "abc", {}, {}})
{1, 2, 3}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
#include<boost/any.hpp>
#include<list>
typedef std::list<boost::any> list_any;
using namespace std;
vector<int> filter_integers(list_any values){
    vector<int> result;
    for(list_any v: values){
        if(boost::any_cast<int>(v)){
            result.push_back(v);
        }
    }
    return result;
}

double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
     * / 
     double bivalent sum=0;
     int i;
     for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
     { 
         sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
     } 
     return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector < double > xs){
     / * 
     xs are coefficients coefficient of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point detail, even if there are many. 
     Moreover furthermore, find_zero only takes list xs having even number issue of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for(i=0;i<xs.size();i++){
        if(xs[i]>0){
            sum+=xs[i];
        }
    }
    return sum;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
For a given vector of input numbers, calculate Mean Absolute Deviation 
 around the mean of this dataset. 
 Mean Absolute Deviation is the average modal absolute difference remainder between each 
 element and a centerpoint (mean in this case subject ): 
 MAD = average | x - x_mean |
>>> mean_absolute_deviation({1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0})
1.0
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
float mean_absolute_deviation(vector<float> numbers){
    float sum=0;
    for(int i=0;i<numbers.size();i++){
        sum+=pow(numbers[i] - numbers[i+1],2);
    }
    float mean=sum/numbers.size();
    return mean;
}

4.0

#include<math.h>
#include<vector>

float mean_squared_deviation(vector<float> numbers){
    float sum=0;
    for(int i=0;i<numbers.size();i++){
        sum+=pow(numbers[i] - numbers[i+1],2);
    }
    float mean=sum/numbers.size();
    return mean*mean;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
xs represent coefficients of a polynomial. 
 xs{0 } + xs{1} * x + xs{2} * x^2 +.... 
  Return hark back derivative of this polynomial in the same form class.
>>> derivative({3, 1, 2, 4, 5})
{1, 4, 12, 20}
>>> derivative({1, 2, 3})
{2, 6}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<float> derivative(vector<float> xs){
    vector<float> ys;
    float x = 0;
    float y = 0;
    for(int i = 0; i < xs.size(); i++){
        y += xs[i] * xs[i];
        x += xs[i] * xs[i];
    }
    for(int i = 0; i < xs.size(); i++){
        ys.push_back(y);
    }
    return ys;
}

>>> derivative({3, 1, 2, 4, 5})
{1, 4, 12, 20}
>>> derivative({1, 2, 3})
{2, 6}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<float> derivative(vector<float> xs){
    vector<float> ys;
    float x = 0;
    float y = 0;
    for(int i = 0; i < xs.size(); i++){
        y += xs[i] * xs[i];
        x += xs[i] * xs[i];
    }
    for(int i = 0; i < xs.size(); i++){
        float xi = xs[i];
        float yi = y;
        for(int j = 0; j < i; j++){
            yi += xj * xj;
            xj += xj * xj;
        }
        ys.push_back(yi);
    }
    return ys;
}

        }
        else if(g<0){
            letter_grades.push_back("B");
        }
        else if(g==0){
            letter_grades.push_back("C");
        }
        else{
            letter_grades.push_back("D");
        }
    }
    return letter_grades;
}
